articles.title: Amnesty International wants NZ visa for climate-affected Pacific islanders
articles.author: Rnz Pacific Journalist
articles.summary: Amnesty International is asking the New Zealand government to create a new humanitarian visa for Pacific people impacted by climate change. Kiribati community leader Charles Kiata said life on the island is becoming extremely hard as sea levels rise and the region is hit by more severe storms, higher temperatures and drought. Amnesty International is also asking the government to stop deporting overstayers from the Pacific, who would be returning to harsh conditions.

articles.title: Nigeria's Sinking Delta
articles.author: Odimegwu Onwumere
articles.summary: Niger Delta under climate change is a story of livelihoods, conflicts, and a fragile ecosystem in peril. The Niger Delta, a region of astonishing biodiversity and immense oil wealth, is disappearing. Niger Delta's coastal plain is being erased by the rising sea. Experts are concerned that a sea-level rise of 20 cm could permanently displace 200 villages along the Delta's coast.

articles.title: Adam Liaw's crepes with mango and raspberry
articles.author: Adam Liaw
articles.summary: Crepes are always a good idea, but adding Australian fruit makes for a dessert that's more delicious than decadent. The whipped cream and sliced mango and raspberries are added to the crepes and serve them with a little bit of melted butter and some icing sugar.

articles.title: La. state reps. urge Pres. Trump, Speaker Johnson to oppose CCS in Louisiana
articles.summary: State lawmakers from Cenla are urging Pres. Trump to oppose carbon capture sequestration development in Louisiana. They are urging him to oppose it on their behalf.       .   in the White House's interest in this matter.

articles.title: La Nina is back, but it's weak and could be brief
articles.author: The Buffalo News
articles.summary: La Nina, the cooler and at times costlier flip side of El Nino, arrived to warp weather worldwide, meteorologists say. It's expected to be cooler and costlier than normal, but not as bad as before. It will be more stable than before.

articles.title: La Nina is here, likely to continue into winter
articles.author: Brian Lada
articles.summary: La Niña is a recurring climate pattern that develops when ocean water near the equator in the central and eastern Pacific becomes cooler than the historical average. It's the counterpart to El Niño. La Niña's effects are most noticeable in winter, shaping where cold air, snow and rain are likely to occur in the United States.

articles.title: Alleged Palisades firebug posted anti-Trump screeds, blamed wildfires on climate change
articles.author: New York Post
articles.summary: Jonathan Rinderknecht is accused of starting the Palisades Fire that burned swaths of Los Angeles to the ground. He regularly posts on social media about how global warming causes wildfires and migrations in the U.S. He is from Melbourne, Florida.

articles.title: Climate disasters ate up one percent of the Bulgarian economy in 2025
articles.author: Maria Atanasova
articles.summary: According to a new study, climate change cost Europe 43 billion euros in 2025. For Bulgaria, the blow is four times stronger. Bulgaria is among the most vulnerable countries in Europe because of its dependence on agriculture and water resources and limited adaptation options. Bulgaria needs to start planning and building with extreme weather in mind.

articles.title: Ernakulam coast lost 25% shoreline in 35 yrs: Study
articles.author: Sudha Nambudiri
articles.summary: Ernakulam coast is rapidly changing, with almost 25% of its shoreline eroding over the past 35 years. Maximum erosion is observed at the coasts of Munambam and Fort Kochi, while maximum accretion (sedimentation) has been identified at Puthuvype.

articles.title: Transforming Nigeria's Farms: A Climate-Smart Revolution for Climate, Health, Nature, and the Economy
articles.author: Jokpeme Joseph Omode
articles.summary: Nigeria's agriculture is threatened by climate change. Floods and droughts have submerged homes and fields in the central regions and parched the northern Sahel, slashing crop yields by up to 30%. Food inflation is soaring at 40%, the economic ripple effects are profound, threatening the stability of a nation where agriculture employs 70% of the workforce and accounts for 25% of GDP. Climate-smart agriculture is a revolution that integrates increased productivity, enhanced resilience and reduced emissions.

articles.title: Long-shuttered Parkton landfill to get new life as Baltimore County solar project
articles.author: Natalie Jones
articles.summary: La Nina is back, but it's weak and may be brief. Will it still amp up the Atlantic hurricane season? It's too early to tell, but the hurricane season is still going to be active. It's not clear if La Nina will be a hurricane force.

articles.title: La Nina Is Back In US: What To Expect This Season
articles.summary: La Nina is back for a second consecutive season and could influence the weather in the United States this autumn and winter. The current La Nina is expected to be relatively weak, with ocean temperatures dropping no more than -0.9 degrees Celsius below average. La Nina will be short-lived, with a 55% chance of returning to neutral conditions by mid-winter.

articles.title: Frank Quevedo on Fall Bird Migration, Best Birding Spots, and What's in the Sky Now
articles.summary: Frank Quevedo is the executive director of the South Fork Natural History Museum and Nature Center. He talks about the current trends in fall bird migration. He recommends early morning birding in the East End of Long Island and going to barrier beaches like Fire Island and Montauk.

articles.title: Drought Fueled by Parched Soils Can Ignite Fires Across the Country
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In summer of 2023, Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas were affected by a severe drought. The study suggests that the origin of the drought lies in dry soil conditions in northern Mexico. The weak North American Monsoon in 2023 led to diminished moisture transfer from the Pacific Ocean over Mexico. This stifled evaporation and subsequent atmospheric moisture recycling, leaving Mexican soils critically desiccated and triggering a cascade of dry air masses moving northward into the American Southwest.

articles.title: La Niña is here. What this means for winter weather — and the rest of hurricane season.
articles.author: Neia Balao
articles.summary: La Niña is officially here. It's a recurring climate pattern that causes colder-than-normal temperatures in the eastern Pacific Ocean. La Niña typically leads to warmer and drier conditions across the southern U.S., and cooler, wetter conditions across northern areas like the Pacific Northwest. This winter's weather will depend on how La Niñas interact with a marine heat wave across the Northern Pacific Ocean, known as 'the blob'.

articles.title: La Niña is here. What this means for winter weather — and the rest of hurricane season.
articles.author: Neia Balao
articles.summary: La Niña is officially here. It's a recurring climate pattern that causes colder-than-normal temperatures in the eastern Pacific Ocean. La Niña typically leads to warmer and drier conditions across the southern U.S., and cooler, wetter conditions across northern areas like the Pacific Northwest. This winter's weather will depend on how La Niñas interact with a marine heat wave across the Northern Pacific Ocean, known as 'the blob'.

articles.title: Billion bird night: 1.25 billion birds flew across the US Wenesday night
articles.author: Jesse Ferrell
articles.summary: On Wednesday night, around 9:40 p.m. EDT, scientists estimated that 1.25 billion birds were in flight, mostly in the Southeast. It was only the third night on record when the number of migrating birds surpassed one billion. Floyd County, Georgia, was near the peak of the migration on Wednesday night when over 20 million birds crossed the county.

articles.title: Climate change is not a ‘con job'
articles.author: The Hill
articles.summary: President Trump has said numerous times that climate change is a hoax. A majority of credible scientists agree that it is real and that it's caused by man-made climate change. Trump said at the UN last month that it was made up by 'stupid people'

articles.title: Believe it or not: snow falls in these African countries
articles.summary: African landscapes are very diverse. Mountain ranges, tropical forests, big lakes, dreamy beaches, and arid deserts are all things you can find in Africa, but the temperatures can go as high as 124°F (51°C) or as low as -4°F (-20°C). Click on to discover which African countries include winter elements as part of their scenery.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record: EU monitor
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: This September was the third-warmest September globally, with an average surface air temperature of 16.11 degrees C, 0.66 degree C above the 1991-2020 average for September. The average temperature for September is 16 degrees C for the 1991 to 2020 period.

articles.title: Equity on the Table: A Conversation about Public Health, Food Access, and Climate Change
articles.summary: Join the Metcalf Institute for a panel discussion with three fellows from the SciComm Identities Project about climate change and its intersection with public health and food equity. The free event will take place in person at the University of Rhode Island and will also be livestreamed.

articles.title: Storms are changing. Should hurricane scale change too?
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As climate change continues to reshape the intensity and behavior of hurricanes, meteorologists and researchers are examining whether the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, a scale based on the current hurricane wind scale, should be updated to reflect the changing climate.

articles.title: New Zealand's oceans warming 34% faster than global average, threatening economy
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: New Zealand's oceans are warming 34% faster than the global average, threatening damage of 180 billion local dollars (about $104 billion) to housing through flooding, according to the Environment Ministry and Stats NZ's report, Our Marine Environment 2025. The ministry and stats NZ's latest report warns that New Zealand's seas are warming.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, the Copernicus Climate Change Service said on Thursday. September was 1.47C above the 1850-1900 average. The current period is likely the warmest the Earth has been for the last 125,000 years.

articles.title: As Tropical Storm Jerry churns in the Atlantic, Priscilla and a nor'easter threaten US with flooding
articles.author: The Sun Chronicle
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Jerry is churning in the Atlantic and is approaching the Leeward Islands on Thursday. It is expected to get worse before it gets better on Friday. It's expected to make landfall on Thursday afternoon or evening. It has a sustained winds of 50 miles per hour.

articles.title: Iconic Sarasota County beachfront attraction opens after hurricane damage repair
articles.author: archives
articles.summary: The T-section of the Venice Municipal Fishing Pier reopened to the public on Sept. 29, after contractors finished replaciing decking and railing damaged during the 2024 hurricane season. The city of Venice partially reopened the pier on Nov. 21, 2024, restoring public access west to the second fish-cleaning station past the bait shop.

articles.title: Maryland needs real climate solutions, not courtroom battles
articles.author: Wendell Beitzel
articles.summary: The climate lawsuits brought by Baltimore, Annapolis and Anne Arundel County are on appeal in the Supreme Court of Maryland. The U.S. Department of Justice has urged the justices to affirm the dismissals, arguing that the claims reach across borders and implicate substantial federal interests. A growing majority of courts have rejected similar suits.

articles.title: Flooding, but no damage reported for Yukon Delta coastal communities after powerful fall storm
articles.author: Kyuk
articles.summary: A severe Bering Sea storm brought flood warnings to a vast swath of Alaska's western coast, leading to evacuations in the Northwest communities of Kotzebue and Kivalina on Wednesday, Oct. 8. In Hooper Bay, waters that inundated low-lying areas in the community had receded by the morning of Oct. 9. Scammon Bay and the road that accesses the community's airport were temporarily flooded. In Nunam Iqua, where the National Weather Service expected some of the worst effects of the storm, no damage was reported.

articles.title: Yahoo News Pushes False Claim Cape Coral Will Vanish Under Rising Seas
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: Yahoo News reposted an article about Cape Coral, Florida disappearing due to climate change-induced sea level rise. The article quotes one resident saying, 'I'm scared. It's weird to think that it's not gonna be here when I'm gone.' The data shows that Cape Coral's sea-level rise is steady and gradual, and less than a third of the 3.6-foot projection from Climate Central.

articles.title: Climate change is not a ‘con job'
articles.author: Rebecca Vega Thurber
articles.summary: President Trump has said numerous times that climate change is a 'hoax' and a 'con job'. A majority of credible scientists agree that it is real and causing massive issues in our world today. Scientists need to remain objective and conduct objective experiments on climate change and environmental research.

articles.title: Opinion: Climate change is not a ‘con job'
articles.author: Rebecca Vega Thurber
articles.summary: President Trump has said numerous times that climate change is a 'hoax' and a 'con job'. A majority of credible scientists agree that it is real and causing massive issues in our world today. Scientists need to remain objective and conduct objective experiments on climate change and environmental research.

articles.title: Hidden crisis: The truth about Australian workplace stress exposed
articles.summary: Australians are 'quietly cracking' at work due to cost-of-living stress and other pressures. The Change Lab research found three quarters of 18 to 24-year-olds were quietly cracking, compared to about a third of those aged 55 years or older. Cost- of-living pressures were the primary driver, responsible for 41.7% of cases. Job security fears (19.7%), AI disruption (5.8%) and other factors also played a role. Jenna Halls lost her mother two years ago.

articles.title: La Niña is here. What does it mean for fall, winter weather in Mississippi? See NOAA forecast
articles.author: Bonnie Bolden
articles.summary: La Niña weather pattern emerged in September 2025. It's the opposite of the more well-known El Nińo, which occurs when Pacific Ocean water is at least 0.9 degrees warmer than average for three months. NOAA's Seasonal Temperature Outlook for fall 2025 forecasts above-normal temperatures across most of the U.S. NOAA predicts anywhere between 33-40% chance of temperatures leaning above normal from September through December in Mississippi. The northernmost parts of the state can expect more precipitation than average while the Gulf Coast could be a little drier than usual.

articles.title: New Zealand's oceans warming 34% faster than global average, threatening economy
articles.author: Asiye Latife Yılmaz
articles.summary: New Zealand's oceans are warming 34% faster than the global average, threatening damage of 180 billion local dollars (about $104 billion) to housing through flooding. New Zealand's location makes it especially vulnerable to climate change. 219,000 homes worth NZ$180 billion and over NZ$26 billion in infrastructure lie in flood-prone zones, with some 1,300 coastal homes at high risk.

articles.title: Tampa Bay Residents Confront Ongoing Challenges One Year After Hurricane Devastation
articles.author: Elizabeth Johanson
articles.summary: It's been a year since Hurricanes Helene and Milton hit the Tampa Bay area. Many people are still living in hotels or with relatives or friends, while others are displaced from their homes. The Ruskin Methodist Church has survived the disaster, despite extensive damages including weathered pews and a costly new roof.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record: EU monitor
articles.summary: This September was the third-warmest September globally, with an average surface air temperature of 16.11 degrees C. The 12-month average temperature from October 2024 to September 2025 was 0.63°C above the 1991-2020 average, and 1.51 degrees C above the pre-industrial level. September was wetter than average in most parts globally including southwestern and central USA, Alaska, northwestern Mexico and in regions of Brazil, Argentina and Chile. NOAA forecast La Nina conditions will set in from October.

articles.title: Will La Niña increase hurricane activity through the rest of season?
articles.author: Christopher Holtzman
articles.summary: The El Niño Southern Oscillation is a climate pattern of shifts in the Pacific Ocean Sea surface temperatures and winds. La Niña has returned and is expected to be around through early next year. It usually brings drier and warmer weather into the Southeast, whereas areas well to our north are cooler and wetter.

articles.title: Widespread rain could usher in more active weather pattern in Minnesota
articles.author: Meteorologist Sven Sundgaard
articles.summary: Sven Sundgaard has the latest on a warmer Thursday with scattered showers late. High pressure returns tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday. Most of Minnesota is abnormally dry and in need of moisture. Widespread rain is possible on Sunday. IPCC has warned that Earth is "firmly on track toward an unlivable world" due to climate change.

articles.title: Dozens of Outer Banks homes remain in peril. More could fall into the sea this week.
articles.author: Brady Dennis
articles.summary: Commissioners in Dare County, North Carolina, are concerned about the houses that keep collapsing into the sea on the Outer Banks and those that might yet give way.    in their meeting earlier this week, the topic dominated all the other topics, except for the houses.

articles.title: La Ni�a Conditions Return
articles.author: g Captain
articles.summary: La Ni�a conditions have emerged in the equatorial Pacific and are expected to persist through the Northern Hemisphere winter. Forecasters predict a 55% chance of transition to ENSO-neutral conditions by early 2026. La Ni’a conditions emerged in September 2025, as indicated by the expansion of below-average sea.

articles.title: New Atlantic storm threatens Caribbean as U.S. watches for Hurricane Jerry
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Jerry is gaining strength and is moving toward the Leeward Islands. Forecasters warn it could become a hurricane by Thursday. It could bring heavy rains, dangerous surf and potential flooding to the area, according to forecasters. It is expected to make landfall on Thursday.

articles.title: InvestigateTV+: Research reveals a dramatic decline in bird populations
articles.author: Wade Smith
articles.summary: There is a dramatic decline in bird populations across North America. Since 1970, 112 bird species have lost more than half their populations. 7th graders from Sacred Heart School are working to protect migratory bird habitat in Rock Creek Park in Washington, D.C. Lola, 6, died of a fungal infection after chemotherapy for leukemia. Fresh Future Farm is working to bring healthy options to North Charleston through food activism.

articles.title: September seen as third-hottest globally on record
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. September did not break the record for the month set in 2023 and was only marginally cooler than the same period last year. Global average temperatures remained stuck near historic highs for yet another month.

articles.title: Global Warming At 3°C By 2050? What's Behind The New German Climate Warning
articles.author: Gabriele Magro
articles.summary: The German Physics Society and the German Meteorological Society warn that global warming is accelerating. They call for decisive action and stronger climate protection to minimize the risk of a 3°C rise by 2050. Since industrialization, it took 65 years for the world to heat by 0.5 °C, but it took just 28 years to reach 1 °C. Oceans have seen a sharp rise in temperature for two and a half years now.

articles.title: Global Gateway Forum: New value chains and new jobs in the Caribbean as the EU and Caribbean tackle the sargassum crisis together (European Commission
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: For over a decade, extensive sargassum seaweed blooms have affected Caribbean coasts disrupting fisheries, tourism and local communities and causing multi-million damage. Through the European Union's (EU) Global Gateway Investment, the EU is investing in the Caribbean.

articles.title: Impacts of Recent Federal and State Actions on Natural Disaster Preparedness and Response on Health
articles.author: -Fs-Body-Md
articles.summary: There are more extreme weather events due to climate change. Low-income communities, people of color, and historically underserved groups are at increased risk of being affected by natural disasters. The Trump administration has recently taken actions that may reverse some of these efforts. The elimination of key offices, programs, and data tools may make it more difficult to assess and mitigate the health risks associated with natural disasters, as climate change-related disasters worsen.

articles.title: La Niña Advisory Issued: warm and dry winter for Houston
articles.author: Allison Gutleber
articles.summary: La Niña conditions are present and are likely to continue through the end of the year. La Niña is due to trade winds and usually brings warmer than average temperatures and drier than normal conditions for Southeast Texas. Conditions are expected to transition to ENSO-neutral in January – March 2026.

articles.title: Staffordshire County Council scraps climate emergency declaration
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Scotgov accused of 'caving to shooting lobby' over muirburn delay
articles.author: Jody Harrison
articles.summary: Muirburn involves intentional and burning of moorland vegetation to encourage new growth. It is a controversial subject in Scotland. Environmentalists argue it disrupts moor's natural lifecycle, damages peat-heavy soils and releases carbon into the atmosphere. Gamekeepers argue it hinders their efforts to keep moors under control, and increases the risk of wildfires. The new start date for the licensing scheme is set for autumn 2026.

articles.title: La Niña Conditions Return
articles.author: Mike Schuler
articles.summary: La Niña conditions have emerged in the equatorial Pacific and are expected to persist through the Northern Hemisphere winter. Forecasters predict a 55% chance of transition to ENSO-neutral conditions by early 2026. The Panama Canal reported impressive financial results for fiscal year 2025, with revenues increasing by 14.4% to $5.7 billion. Vessel transits also rose 19.3% year-on-year to 13,404 during the 12-month period ending September 30.

articles.title: A trio of tropical systems is driving significant Southwest flood threat
articles.author: Shane O Neill
articles.summary: Remnants of two recent East Pacific hurricanes and a developing storm off the Mexican coast are setting up a long-lived channel of deep tropical moisture that is targeting the Desert Southwest. The result will be several days of flood risk, including a major threat across Arizona to end the workweek.

articles.title: North Simcoe heads praised for proactive green change: SSEA
articles.author: Derek Howard
articles.summary: Jonathan Main, the sustainability and climate action coordinator for the Severn Sound Environmental Association, presented a dense update tailored to area councils. The update focused on the fourth of five milestones regarding plan implementation. Georgian Bay watershed municipalities including Midland, Penetanguishene, and Tay and Tiny Townships received the update.

articles.title: September marks third-hottest month on record: Report
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. Global average temperatures remained stuck near historic highs for the whole of the year, as well as for the last few months of the last decade.

articles.title: Another Disruptive Deluge
articles.author: Daily Guide
articles.summary: There was a four-hour downpour in Accra last Tuesday. Accra has seen many disruptive downpours, some of them fatal. The June 3, 2015 Circle disaster left in its trail deaths and destructions. The political will to enforce construction bylaws is lacking in the nation's capital.

articles.title: North American ice sheets drove dramatic sea-level rise at end of last ice age, study finds
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: melting ice sheets in North America played a far greater role in driving global warming than in Europe and Africa.    in the past few centuries.  in modern era   and in the present era  and today  and now  and   today.

articles.title: How hot was September 2025? Copernicus report breaks it down
articles.author: Hannah Docter Loeb
articles.summary: This was the third-warmest September globally. The average surface air temperature was 16.11°C, which is 0.66°C above the 1991-2020 average for September. The warmest September on record was in 2023. The ocean temperature was 20.72°C. Eastern Europe and Fennoscandia saw the most pronounced above-average air temperatures. Western Europe saw cooler-than-average temperatures. Europe was wetter than usual.

articles.title: Male or female? Chinese scientists find gene that determines central bearded dragon's sex
articles.author: Holly Chik
articles.summary: In arid parts of central Australia, temperature plays a big part in determining whether central bearded dragon embryos emerge from their eggs as male or female. If incubated at 32 degrees Celsius (89.6 degrees Fahrenheit) or higher, some male embryos will emerge as female, while if the temperature is cooler, genetics will determine the sex and these males will remain males.

articles.title: Songbirds need joined-up action before it's too late
articles.author: Sue Morgan
articles.summary: Half of the 84 UK breeding songbird species are threatened or in decline. Agri-environment schemes are helping some species like corn bunting and skylark to slowly recover, but they will soon be coming to an end. There needs to be joined-up policy, long-term support for farmers and national commitment to restoring habitats.

articles.title: Afghanistan and Qatar Discuss Climate Cooperation as Drought and Water Crisis Deepen
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: Afghanistan and Qatar discussed expanding climate cooperation as worsening droughts and a growing water crisis threaten the country's environment and livelihoods. Both sides stressed the importance of keeping environmental and social challenges free from political influence. Afghanistan is a signatory to 16 international treaties and conventions on environmental protection.

articles.title: Cost of Europe's extreme weather has doubled this decade
articles.author: Liam Gilliver
articles.summary: The European Environment Agency (EEA) has calculated the average annual economic losses caused by climate-related events from 1980 to 2023. The yearly cost reached an all-time high of €44.5 billion. The biggest losses came from the 2021 floods in Belgium, Germany, and the Netherlands, which are believed to have caused more than €40 billion worth of damage. Italy suffered the biggest losses, with projected losses surpassing €11 billion in 2025 and forecast of €34.2 billion by 2029.

articles.title: Tunisia calls for fair and accessible climate financing for Africa
articles.author: APA-Tunis
articles.summary: At the Second African Climate Summit in Addis Ababa, Tunisia called for 'equitable and accessible' climate financing to support the most vulnerable countries facing global warming. The NDC for 2021-2030 requires 19.4 billion for mitigation and 4.3 billion for adaptation. Tunisia can only mobilize 23 percent of the total from its own resources. The rest is dependent on international support, primarily through grants and lines of credit.

articles.title: MS Coast locals, Louisiana transplants are leaving Bay St. Louis for this tiny farm town
articles.author: Sun Herald
articles.summary: Clark Breland moved to the Kiln from Bay St. Louis a few years ago. The area's population has grown by 30% in the last decade, according to the Census Bureau. The high ground can soothe fears of the next catastrophic hurricane. The challenges are leaving the community more splintered.

articles.title: Government and partners can reduce the climate change risks to wildlife
articles.author: Associate Editor
articles.summary: Climate change has a significant impact on wildlife conservation in South Sudan. South Sudan is already struggling with environmental fragility, recurring conflicts, and a high dependence on natural resources. The government needs to develop and enforce conservation policies that integrate climate change considerations. The interlinked challenges of energy poverty and climate change contribute to the degradation of natural resources in the country.

articles.title: Cradle to Grave: The health toll of fossil fuels and the imperative for a just transition
articles.author: Graham Wroe
articles.summary: The report on the Health Consequences of Fossil Fuels has been published by the Global Health and Climate Alliance. It shows the full scale of the health impacts of coal, oil, and gas. Almost all of the global population (99%) breathe air that exceeds WHO guideline limits and contains high levels of pollutants. People living close to fracking sites have a double incidence of childhood leukaemia and the elderly are suffering from increased rates of dementia. Fossil fuels are directly and explicitly subsidised to the tune of $1.3 trillion by governments and indirectly supported by $5.7 trillion.

articles.title: All the parts of England that won't see snow in October with 29 counties spared
articles.author: James Rodger
articles.summary: All the parts of England that won't see snow in October with 29 counties spared. Maps from WX Charts suggest wintriness could sweep across the Pennines. Cumbria, Northumberland, Durham, Yorkshire, Lancashire, and Greater Manchester, and Cheshire and Derbyshire, could face flurries.

articles.title: Melting Antarctic Sea Ice Could Release Trapped Carbon and Speed Up Global Warming
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: At the end of the last Ice Age, the sea ice off the coast of Antarctica began to melt. This reduced pressure in the ocean, which slowed down a process that helps trap carbon dioxide deep in the sea. The planet warmed much faster. Today, the Antarctic sea ice is shrinking again, raising questions about how this ocean process might change and affect our climate.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record
articles.author: Naharnet
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. The global temperature in September 2025 was the third warmest on record. It was almost as high as in September 2024, but a tenth of a degree cooler.

articles.title: What is the economical impact of hurricane season?
articles.summary: Hurricane seasons bring significant economic repercussions. Communities face rising costs for repairs, insurance, and recovery, while local and national economies may experience job losses and decreased productivity. Understanding the economic impacts of hurricanes is essential for preparing and mitigating future risks.    Click on to explore the economic implications of hurricane season.

articles.title: North American Ice Sheets Drove Last Deglaciation Sea-Level Rise
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Earth's climate system is a complex interplay between the ocean, atmosphere, and cryosphere. Sea-level change serves as a crucial integrator, linking ice melt, ocean circulation, and atmospheric conditions. The study's findings bear significant implications for understanding the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC).

articles.title: September marks third-hottest month on record: Report
articles.author: Afp
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. September was 1.47 degrees Celsius (2.6 degrees Fahrenheit) above the 1850-1900 average. The current period is likely the warmest the Earth has been for the last 125,000 years.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Jerry churns in the Atlantic as a weakened Priscilla nears Mexico's Baja peninsula
articles.summary: Priscilla has lost hurricane strength as it churns off Mexico's western Pacific coast. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Jerry has strengthened in the Atlantic as it approaches the Baja California peninsula.    .   i   in the  Atlantic as Tropical Storm

articles.title: Gardeners encouraged to leave out common fruit for robins in October
articles.author: cornwalllive@reachplc.com
articles.summary: Gardeners are encouraged to leave raisins for robins in their gardens this October. Robins do not migrate south for winter, leaving them at the mercy of the icy British winter. Ark Wildlife recommends suet pellets, fat balls, fruits and berries, mealworms and calcium worms.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, the Copernicus Climate Change Service said on Thursday. Global average temperatures remained stuck near historic highs for another month. September 2025 was the third warmest on record. September 2024 was less than a tenth of a degree cooler.

articles.title: Discriminatory Migration System Fails Pacific People Facing Climate Change And Disasters
articles.author: New Zealand Labour Party
articles.summary: Aotearoa New Zealand discriminates against Pacific Islanders affected by climate change and disasters. Amnesty International's new report is titled Navigating Injustice: Climate Displacement from the Pacific Islands of Tuvalu and Kiribati to New Zealand. The Pacific Islands are most at risk of climate-related harm in the Pacific islands, subjecting them to discriminatory migration policies.

articles.title: Ahead of the fire season, Cape Winelands residents urged to remove any potential fire hazards around their homes
articles.author: Eye Witness News
articles.summary: The warning comes as the municipality shifts focus to warmer temperatures and the annual fire season, which is expected to be warmer and wetter than usual this year, and the warning comes from the municipality's firefighting agency.    i.e. the municipality is preparing for the warmer temperatures.

articles.title: Temperatures Stay Near Historic Highs, Earth Records 3rd-Hottest September
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: The world just had its third-hottest September on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. September did not break the record for the month set in 2023 and was only marginally cooler than the same period last year. Global average sea surface temperature reached 20.72°C, the third-highest on record for September.

articles.title: La Niña Effect on North India: Harsh Winter Conditions Expected
articles.author: Anjali Rawat
articles.summary: La Niña is expected to change the weather in North India during the winter of 2025-26. There will be fewer western disturbances and more stable atmospheric patterns that trap cold air masses over the region. The La Niña impact on Delhi weather includes minimum temperatures dropping 2-4°C below normal and frequent cold wave conditions when temperatures fall below 5°C for extended periods. Dense fog and poor air quality (AQI >400) disrupt transport. Wheat and mustard yields may drop.

articles.title: Compound Typhoon Disaster Risks in Southeastern China
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In the study, Yang, Yan, Zhou, and colleagues studied the complex dynamic of disaster chains triggered by typhoons in Southeastern China. The research sheds light on the intricate risk patterns formed when multiple disaster events cascade and compound, challenging traditional single-event risk assessment frameworks. The study also highlights the temporal dimension of disaster chain risks.

articles.title: UN Warns Drought Threatens Families Across Afghanistan
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: Afghanistan is experiencing a severe drought. The drought has dried up water sources, destroyed crops and left millions of families struggling with hunger and survival. OCHA has begun providing emergency cash assistance to the most vulnerable households to buy food and water. Mercy Corps has warned that Afghanistan faces an escalating water crisis.

articles.title: Residents scramble to save coastal village from worsening crisis: 'We're not going to get much help'
articles.author: Alyssa Ochs
articles.summary: The northeastern coast of Scotland is seeing significant sea level rises and worsening erosion. The small village of Johnshaven, with a population of 640, is dangerously exposed to the rising seas and is desperately seeking a way to save the town. If no action is taken, at least 100 houses in the area are at risk of flooding.

articles.title: 458 Dead In Jharkhand This Year In Heaviest Monsoon In A Decade
articles.author: Press Trust
articles.summary: This year's monsoon in Jharkhand was one of the most intense in a decade. 458 people were killed by lightning strikes, flooding, landslides, and house collapses, while 178 drowned in rain-related incidents. Floods destroyed 467 houses, damaged over 8,000 hectares of crops, and displaced 20,000 people in Sahibganj. East Singhbhum topped the list with 1,669.5 mm of rainfall, followed by Saraikela-Kharsawan (1.526.3 mm), and Ranchi (1,550.2 mm). IMD has forecast isolated moderate rain with thunder and lightning in some areas until October 12.

articles.title: Jharkhand Faces Heaviest Monsoon in a Decade; Over 458 Dead as Floods, Landslides, and Lightning Devastate State
articles.author: Syed Muskan Shafiq
articles.summary: This year's monsoon season brought unprecedented rainfall to Jharkhand, with total precipitation measuring 1,199.5 millimetres-18% above the long-term average. The state recorded a devastating blend of floods, landslides, and lightning incidents between June and September. 458 people died, including 186 from lightning strikes and 178 from rain-related incidents such as floods and collapses. Hundreds of homes-467 fully destroyed and over 8,000 partially damaged-have left tens of thousands of families homeless, while displacement figures reach into the hundreds of thousands.

articles.title: EU climate agency reports world's third-warmest September
articles.author: 刘小卓
articles.summary: The world has just experienced its third warmest September on record, according to EU's climate monitoring network. The global average surface temperature in September this year was 16.11 degrees Celsius. Sea surface temperatures in September were 20.72 degrees Celsius, the third highest for this month on record. The monthly sea ice extent in the Arctic was 12 percent below the long-term average for the period.

articles.title: Why India Could Face A Colder Than Usual Winter: La Nina Explained
articles.summary: India is expecting a colder-than-average winter this year due to La Nina climate phenomenon. This is a weather pattern where ocean temperatures in the Central and Eastern Pacific drop below normal, which shifts wind patterns, rainfall, and winter. The temperatures in Delhi fell below 20 degrees Celsius at several weather stations, with the lowest at 17.6 degrees recorded at Ridge in north Delhi, followed by 18.4 degrees at Palam.

articles.title: Copernicus: 3rd warmest September globally
articles.author: Stella Meehan
articles.summary: September 2025 was the third-warmest September globally, with an average surface air temperature of 16.11°C, 0.66°C above the 1991-2020 average for September. The most pronounced above-average air temperatures were recorded over Fennoscandia and eastern Europe. It was drier than average in parts of Canada, eastern US, north-eastern Mexico, northern and easternmost Russia, and north of the Indian subcontinent.

articles.title: September 2025 recorded as third-hottest on record
articles.summary: 2025 is on track to be the third-hottest year on record, after 2024 and 2023. September 2025 was 1.47°C warmer than the average temperature between 1850 and 1900. Global temperatures have been steadily rising due to greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuels since the industrial revolution.

articles.title: EU climate agency reports world's third-warmest September
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: The world has just experienced its third warmest September on record. Land and sea surface temperatures remain persistently high, according to EU's climate monitoring network. Global temperature context remains much the same, due to the continuing influence of greenhouse gas accumulation in the atmosphere.

articles.title: Grounded rapid-response fire trucks add to pressure on CFA brigades as summer looms
articles.author: Jack Colantuono
articles.summary: Hundreds of firefighting vehicles grounded due to safety concerns. The vehicles were part of a $32 million government investment made in 2017 to strengthen the state's firefighting capacity. Country firefighters fear the withdrawal of the vehicles will put extra pressure on local brigades. The government is fast-tracking repairs to the grounded fleet.

articles.title: Devastating Monsoon Hits Jharkhand: Record Rainfall and Rising Casualties
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Jharkhand had its most severe rainfall event in a decade. 458 people died due to the torrential rains and related disasters between June and September. The monsoon completely destroyed 467 houses and partially damaged over 8,000 hectares of farmlands. IMD forecasts mild winter conditions will follow the monsoon.

articles.title: Directing climate finance to local solutions
articles.summary: Uganda is living through the harsh realities of climate change. The country committed to reducing its GHG emissions by 24.7 percent below business-as-usual levels by 2030. Most of the mitigation is expected to come from agriculture, forestry, and other land use. There is a gap in access to climate finance at the grassroots. Local Governments, farmer groups, and Community-Based Organizations (CBOs) should decentralise resources to local communities.

articles.title: Magpies: Australia's Surprising Attackers From the Air
articles.author: Aachener-zeitung.de
articles.summary: A bird is causing controversy in Australia. Europeans usually associate respect-inspiring animals with Australia, such as spiders, snakes, crocodiles or sharks, but at the moment, a bird is also causing turmoil.   Â      in Australia,

articles.title: Climate change: Dorset residents to help shape response
articles.author: Deb Gayen
articles.summary: The Dorset Citizens' Climate Panel will help shape the county's response to climate change issues. The initiative is part of Dorset Council's effort to build resilient communities and involve residents in decision-making. The panel will produce a set of recommendations to inform Dorset's plan for dealing with the local impacts of climate change. The recommendations will be shared with those working on climate response and used to inform the development of county's adaptation strategy.

articles.title: What's Coming Up - Insight On The Philippines' Flooding Problem: Is It Now The New Norm?
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Flooding is the new normal in the Philippines due to rising sea levels and extreme weather. Can Filipinos adapt to a future defined by constant flooding and climate change? In Insight investigates.    in the video below, Insight looks into the issue.

articles.title: Climate Realism Is Winning
articles.author: Chris Talgo
articles.summary: As climate alarmism wanes, climate realism waxes. Heartland Institute released the second edition of its quintessential guide to climate realism: Climate at a Glance (Second Edition): Facts on 40 Prominent Climate Topics. The previous version achieved Amazon best-seller status in categories like 'Science for Kids,' 'Climatology,' and 'Environmental Science.'

articles.title: South Africa's major climate threats — from drought to deadly heatwaves
articles.author: Sheree Bega
articles.summary: The biggest economic risk that South Africa faces from climate change is the possibility of a climate-induced drought. Last year, the world exceeded the 1.5°C threshold of global warming. The Paris Agreement aimed to achieve a 45% emissions reduction by 2030 (relative to 2010 levels) and net-zero emissions by 2050.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record: Climate monitor
articles.summary: September 2025 was the third-hottest September globally according to the Copernicus ERA5 dataset. The 10-year temperature anomaly has increased from-0.7°C to +0.43°C since 1940. Global surface temperatures rose to 1.1°C above pre-industrial levels from 2011 to 2020.

articles.title: Heavy rain and widespread flood risks threaten regions
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Heavy rain is creating serious flood and landslide risks across the country. In Bac Ninh, water levels on the Thuong and Cau rivers have exceeded historic highs. There have been three fatalities and over 10,000 households relocated, 1,800 households isolated, one reservoir breached, 500m of canal damaged, and multiple roads, dykes, and farmland inundated.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record: climate monitor
articles.author: Gulf News
articles.summary: September 2025 was the third hottest September since 1940, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service data integrated by Our World in Data. The global temperature in September 2025 was nearly as high as in September 2024, less than a tenth of a degree cooler.

articles.title: Japan's top insurer bets on engineering acquisition to mitigate climate risk
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Why African cities have failed to adapt to climate change
articles.author: The Conversation Africa
articles.summary: At least 443 people have been killed in the floods in Durban, South Africa. The current system of social, economic and political structures that cities are based on is built on a market-led capitalist model and globalisation. Cities need to adapt to a changing climate and its intensifying hazards such as floods, droughts or intense heat. The solution is a transformative adaptation.

articles.title: September third-hottest globally on record: Climate monitor
articles.summary: September recorded the third-highest global temperature. Global average temperatures remain near historic highs. Scientists warn that even small temperature increases destabilize the planet. Nations will gather in Brazil for UN climate negotiations next month. Major economies are not reducing emissions enough to avoid severe climate change impacts.

articles.title: Current 'five times stronger' than Gulf Stream sparks global disaster fears after slowdown
articles.author: Richard Ashmore
articles.summary: Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) is five times stronger than the Gulf Stream. ACC is 100 times larger in volume than the Amazon River and circulates around the frozen South Pole continent of Antarctica. The ACC is undergoing a slowdown in speed and power. Rising temperatures could slow the ACC by 20% by 2050.

articles.title: Watt confirms there will be no climate trigger in reform of EPBC nature laws
articles.author: Renew Economy
articles.summary: The reworked environmental laws will not include a climate trigger, the federal environment minister has confirmed.   .       "The new laws do not include such a trigger" as previously thought.  "There will be no climate trigger"

articles.title: Labor Minister's latest climate change claim hinged on 'implausible' scenario contained in National Climate Risk Assessment
articles.author: Laurence Karacsony
articles.summary: The National Climate Risk Assessment painted a dystopian picture of Australia's future, warning the nation would suffer a loss in property value of $611 billion by 2050 and $770 billion by 2100 if global temperatures were to rise by 3C from current levels. Regional Development Minister Kristy McBain referenced the report's warning that there would be not a single Australian community 'immune' from climate risks. Professor Roger Pielke said the government's climate change risk assessment hinged on 'implausible' scenarios.

articles.title: On the highway to Hellbourne
articles.author: David Llewellyn-Smith
articles.summary: I have just returned from a rock-n-roll thunder tour of the world that took in Tokyo, London, Amsterdam, Paris, and Rome. He has not visited any of these cities in 40 years, so the changes were amazing. Tokyo has barely changed as an experience, except that it has gone from horrifyingly expensive to spectacularly cheap. Amsterdam, London and Paris have been polished by globalisation to the point of becoming parodies of themselves. Rome was grungy, but still grungy enough to offer a real past expressed legitimately. Hellbourne has the highest quality and greatest array of cuisine in the world. Uber is a lot cheaper here than everywhere else, thanks to the

articles.title: Residents stunned as beloved natural feature disappears before their eyes: 'The change has been so fast'
articles.author: Kristen Carr
articles.summary: The North Cascades in Washington's North Cascade Mountains have nearly 100 named glaciers, which is more than any other area of the United States. Since the Industrial Revolution, carbon dioxide and other pollutants have raised temperatures, causing glaciers to melt at a rapid rate. This summer was the fourth-warmest and seventh-driest since 1895. The runoff that supports the salmon is also warming, disrupting the balance of ecosystems.

articles.title: Aussie Bird Count is back
articles.author: Cobram Courier
articles.summary: The 2025 Aussie Bird Count is Australia's favourite citizen science event. It takes place during springtime and is organised by the Aussies for Bird Counting. It's the first event of its kind in the world and is led by the Australian Bird Count.

articles.title: Gwadar's hidden flood-II
articles.author: Pazeer Ahmed
articles.summary: Sea level rise has more than doubled in the past three decades. Global sea levels are projected to rise by an additional 6.6 inches (169 millimetres) during the next 30 years. Sea levels at Gwadar could rise between 0.44 and 1.03 meters over the next 75 years. In recent times, demand for groundwater has gone up due to drought.

articles.title: 'Shocked': Interactive online map reveals the impact of the net zero rollout
articles.author: Jason Matthews
articles.summary: A new interactive map has gone live showing the scale of Australia's proposed net-zero rollout. Conservationist and photographer Steven Nowakowski joined Jason Matthews on 4BC Mornings to discuss the map. You can view the map HERE and download the 4BC App on iOS or Android.

articles.title: Ancient wisdom can help tackle extreme heat-Ecns.cn
articles.summary: Zhao Li is the editor of China Daily. He argues that China's response to the climate change crisis is based on centuries-old cultural understanding and state-of-the-art technology. China has established an advanced weather-monitoring and risk-mitigating network that spans "air, land, sea and space".

articles.title: ‘Humanitarian' visa must be created for Pacific Islanders displaced by climate crisis, experts say
articles.author: Lagipoiva Cherelle Jackson
articles.summary: Amnesty International has called on New Zealand to reform its immigration policies to provide a dedicated humanitarian visa for Pacific Islanders displaced by climate change. At least 50,000 Pacific Islanders each year face the risk of displacement from climate impacts such as sea level rise and extreme weather. New Zealand's Pacific Access Category, which uses a lottery system and strict health requirements excludes older people, those with disabilities, and others most vulnerable to climate impacts.

articles.title: Antarctic Ocean of the last ice age reveals how a critical process of CO₂ storage ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The sea ice retreated off the coast of Antarctica and is heading toward the southernmost continent like it did in the 1980s and 1990s. The sea ice is retreating toward the Antarctic continent.      Â   in the area of Antarctica.

articles.title: Storm Surge announces next speaker series discussion
articles.author: Gloucester Daily Times
articles.summary: Storm Surge Newburyport presents "Climate Change and Shellfishing in the Merrimack River: End of a Legacy or a New Beginning?" on Oct. 21 at 7 p.m. at the Senior/Community Center, 331 High St., Newburburyport.

articles.title: How our "knowledge system" catastrophizes the side-effects of fossil fuels
articles.author: Alex Epstein
articles.summary: The mainstream knowledge system has a track record of catastrophizing the side-effects of fossil fuels. It has also catastrophized resource availability, environmental quality and nuclear energy. Bill McKibben and Paul Ehrlich predicted catastrophic resource depletion and global cooling.

articles.title: Australian Climate Risk Assessment issues dire warnings
articles.summary: Australia's first National Climate Risk Assessment warned of the accelerating danger of climate change. The report predicted extreme heat and heatwaves, significant sea level rise and increased coastal hazards affecting millions of people. The annual cost of climate-driven disasters could be $40 billion by 2050. Australia needs to commit to a 75 percent reduction in emissions by 2030.

articles.title: ‘Humanitarian' visa must be created for Pacific Islanders displaced by climate crisis, experts say
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Calls for reform to allow people threatened by climate crisis to more easily migrate to New Zealand, especially people from the Pacific.   Â. Â   “Climate crisis” is a term used to refer to the current global warming.

articles.title: 24 Years Of NASA Satellite Data Suggest The World Is Getting Darker, And It's Happening Faster In The North
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: The Earth is getting darker and there are significant differences between the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, according to a new study looking at data from 24 years of NASA satellite surveys. The rest of the article is behind a paywall, so please sign in or subscribe to access the full content.

articles.title: 10 Years After Paris Agreement, Countries Are Still Missing Climate Deadlines
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: The 2015 Paris Agreement was inked nearly a decade ago. It states that global temperature rise should be limited to well below 2 degrees Celsius [3.6 degrees Fahrenheit] over preindustrial levels. The treaty hinges on almost 200 countries, but they are insufficient to keep to the goals of the agreement.

articles.title: Climate change effects expected to hurt farm viability in next decade, study finds
articles.author: RNZ
articles.summary: The future of farming is expected to be affected by climate change. Research consultancy firm Kōmanawa Solutions ran 295 million weather simulations with past weather data on a catchment in North Canterbury. The study found that bad years will become worse and more frequent in the future.

articles.title: Ernakulam coast lost 25% shoreline in 35 yrs: Study
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Ernakulam lost almost 12km of the 46km shoreline from 1988 to 2023. The sea erosion is aggressive in some areas. The study was published in 'Coastal Environments of India' volume of volume of 'Coasts of India'.

articles.title: Greenpeace Accuses Russia of Destroying the Environment
articles.author: Oil Price
articles.summary: A new Greenpeace report documents Russia's environmental policies and practices causing global harm. The report is titled Fossil Fuel Empire: Active engagement in the 1990s to deliberate detachment and obstructionism in recent years and documents Russia’s role in the global warming crisis.

articles.title: September ‘third-hottest globally on record'
articles.author: Hürriyet Daily News
articles.summary: the world just had its third-hottest September on record, the warmest September ever recorded.    for September.  for the hottest September ever, according to the scientists.  For more information, go to: http://www.bbc.com/

articles.title: Louisiana Radar Misleads Some to Believe Rain is Approaching
articles.author: Chris Reed
articles.summary: Temperatures are beginning to drop in the southern region as we approach mid-October. Migratory birds are now on the move, and many are flying further southward now as temperatures begin to drop up north. For some hunters, this could be a blessing. Rodents will also be moving south as the temperatures drop.
